title.narrative: Provision of Emergency Primary Health Care Services through mobile health teams to drought affected people in Ghor, Kunduz and Herat provinces

description.narrative: The proposed project will provide emergency primary health care services in the priority districts under the 2018 3rd reserve allocation targeting both non-displaced drought-affected people and drought induced IDPs in Herat, Ghor and Kunduz provinces. Intervention will take place in four districts in Hirat [Enjeel, Zinda Jan, Kushk (known as Robat Sangi) and Kushki Kohna districts, three districts in Ghor (Du Layna, Taywara, and Feroz Koh district), and two districts of Kunduz (Khan Abad and Disth e Archi)]. There are already approved mobile teams under the second standard allocation 2018 that provide nutrition and protection services in Herat and Ghor provinces- The health component will integrate into the integrated mobile nutrition and protection teams in 4 districts of Herat (Enjeel, Zinda Jan, Kushk, Kushki Kohna) and one district (Du Layna) of Ghor. Selection of the proposed provinces are based on the 2018 reserve strategy with an added value of HN-TPO presence in all these provinces as well as other factors such as concentration of direct beneficiaries, and gaps in the services in the selected districts. Services to non-displaced drought-affected people and drought-induced IDPs will be provided through mobile health teams (MHTs) each staffed with MD, midwife, vaccinator, 2 psycho-social counselors and 1 community mobilizer) and the driver. The MHT structure is based on the MoPH mobile health team composition. The MHTs will provide services through the fixed Service Delivery Points (SDPs) and through community outreach sessions in the SDP catchment area. A total of 4 new MHTs will be established in Ghor (2 MHTs) and Kunduz ( 2 MHTs). While the exiting 4 other mobile teams from 2018 2nd standard allocation will be upgraded by inclusion of health component. This up gradation will take place in 3 existing mobile in Hirat and 1 in Ghor. The list of drought affected villages provided by the Provincial Disaster Management Agency (PNDMA) as well as data from NRC assessment in July shows 51,810 drought induced IDPs over 179 collective sites in Enjeel district. During the inception phase of the project, the exact locations for SDPs and target villages will be identified in consultation with PPHD, OCHA and district authorities.The composition of the MHT in the targeted four districts in Hirat province will be 3 MHTs, for Angeel where there is a subset of the IDPs settled in several collective sites will be covered by one MHT. The other three target districts of Hirat will be covered with two IMHTs – one for Zinda Jan, and another for Kushk (also knowsn as Robat Sangi), and Kushki Kohna districts. In Ghor province, 3 MHT will provide health services to drought-affected people in Du Layna, Changhcharan (Feroz Koh), and Taywar districts. 2 MHTs will be newly established and 1 in Du Layna districts existing mobile will be upgraded with health components. In Kunduz province, Two MHTs will provide health services - one in Khan Abad and one in Dasth-e-archi district. The proposed AHF-2018 Reserve Fund project has been designed in view of the 2018 Humanitarian Need Overview (HNO) and the 2018-21 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) – the original and revised HRP – in close coordination with Health cluster (WHO) at central and regional level with regional OCHA offices, the Hirat, Kunduz and Ghor provincial PHDs, the BPHS/EPHS implementers, The inception phase will include a rapid assessment of target areas, mapping of the population, orientation and coordination with community and provincial authorities and identifying the service delivery points (SDPs). The inception phase activities will be carried out during the 15 days of the project, by provincial team and project manager and other staff from central office. Coordination with the target population and project stakeholders has been taken into consideration as integral components of the project. Focus is given to gender issues in selection of beneficiaries and in team composition
